claim.hypotheses_location: Propositions and corollaries stated in the theoretical section (e.g., Proposition 1–4 and related corollaries) of the main text

data.source: Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) survey; Flash Eurobarometer Survey on Entrepreneurship (FESE); U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base (IDB) for population; additional country characteristics (e.g., GDP per capita, GDP growth, share of agriculture, tertiary education rates, startup costs, property rights index, compulsory military service length)
data.wave_or_subset: GEM: 2001–2010 across 82 countries; FESE: 2002–2009 (OECD-focused; China excluded in FESE as the only developing country). Analyses by OECD vs. non-OECD and age-specific (45 age groups) subsets.
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual respondents; aggregated country–age–year cells; country–year panels
data.notes: Entrepreneurship primarily defined as owning/managing a business <42 months old (early-stage); alternative definitions used for robustness (e.g., startups, businesses that died within last 42 months, non-wage payers, high-aspiration entrepreneurs). Sampling weights use IDB age-structure. Demographic parameter r summarizes age distribution and predicts median age; model achieves high fit (e.g., R² ≈ .998 for demographic predictions). FESE used for cross-validation with GEM; China excluded from FESE.

method.description: The study combines a demographic-theory model (rank effect and advantages of youth vs. business acumen) with empirical analysis using GEM and FESE. It estimates reduced-form regressions at country-year and country–age group levels, relating entrepreneurship rates to demographic structure (median age and a population shrinkage parameter r), the share of younger population (s_a), age and age-squared, and macro controls. Country fixed effects and multiple definitions of entrepreneurship are used for robustness. Theoretical propositions predict lower entrepreneurship in older societies and an inverted U-shaped relationship between age and entrepreneurship, peaking in middle age.
steps: Construct demographic measures from IDB, including median age and the demographic parameter r; compute shares younger than age a (s_a).
Define entrepreneurship outcomes from GEM (primary: business <42 months old) and assemble comparable FESE measures for validation.

Create country–year and country–age–year panels with entrepreneurship rates and covariates (GDP per capita, GDP growth, agriculture share, tertiary education, startup costs, property rights index, compulsory military service length).
Estimate reduced-form regressions of entrepreneurship on r and median age, with and without controls, at country-year level; include country fixed effects where applicable.
Estimate age-specific regressions allowing nonlinear age effects (age and age-squared) and including s_a to test theoretical corollaries; run versions with country fixed effects.
Conduct robustness checks using alternative entrepreneurship definitions and the FESE dataset; compare GEM–FESE concordance.
Interpret coefficients in light of theoretical propositions (e.g., rank effect, inverted U-shape), and quantify effects such as differences between countries with distinct r.
method.models: Reduced-form OLS regressions at country-year and country–age–year levels; specifications include age and age-squared terms, demographic parameters (r, median age), share younger (s_a), macro controls, and country fixed effects. Theoretical model of age structure influencing skill acquisition and entrepreneurship (rank effect) supports empirical tests.
method.outcome_variable: Entrepreneurship rate or indicator of owning/managing a business less than 42 months old (early-stage entrepreneurship); alternative definitions used in robustness checks.
method.independent_variables: Demographic parameter r (population shrinkage/ageing), median age, share of population younger than age a (s_a), age, age-squared; additional covariates including GDP per capita, GDP growth, agriculture share, tertiary education rates, startup costs, property rights index, compulsory military service length.
method.control_variables: GDP per capita, GDP growth, share of agriculture in GDP, tertiary education rates/college enrollment, startup costs, intellectual property/property rights index, compulsory military service length; country fixed effects in some specifications.

results.summary: Entrepreneurship declines with population aging: a one standard deviation lower median age is associated with a 2.5 percentage point higher new business formation rate (about 40% of the mean). Older societies have lower entrepreneurship at every age, consistent with a rank effect where younger workers in older populations gain skills more slowly. Within countries, entrepreneurship follows an inverted U-shape over age, peaking in the early 30s (around 32), and middle-aged groups are most sensitive to demographic aging. The demographic parameter r is negatively associated with entrepreneurship in both full and OECD samples, robust to controls and alternative outcome definitions. Model-based comparisons imply substantially higher entrepreneurship in younger countries (e.g., predicted U.S. rate 61% higher than Japan).
